## About
I am committed, inquisitive and a goal oriented mobile and software engineer with cloud computing skills (AWS) who's passionate about learning, teaching, building great technology, writing about what I know and above all connecting with like minded people to create positive change.
I love the challenges that comes with solving problems and would look into your coding problems for the love of it. Feel free to connect with me here and @adomhamza elsewhere.

Well, I didn't know at the time that I was playing a key role in product building until I transitioned into product design. It now makes more sense why they are very key when it comes to getting valuable product insights. Support teams are usually the first to hear where users are stuck, confused, or frustrated. Here are ways to get actionable insights from your support team: → Review support tickets during discovery to spot recurring pain points → Join customer success syncs when you can to hear real user feedback → Use reported issues to guide usability improvements → Include a support representative during design reviews to get practical input → Spot trends in support data that can replace or guide user research Support teams bring empathy and deep context from users. They should be part of key product decisions. If you have a product out there, work closely with them. It will improve how useful and relevant your solutions are. [
InternPulse
](https://ng.linkedin.com/company/internpulse?trk=public_profile_relatedPosts_face-pile-cta)[The secret to landing your first job? It's not just about what you can do. Aisha was a sharp software developer. Her code was clean, her logic impeccable. But during an interview at a tech company in Lagos, she came across as… well, let's just say "proud." She talked about her past achievements with a bit of a "know-it-all" vibe, and when the interviewer asked about her experience working in a team, she shrugged and said, "I prefer to work independently. Teamwork slows me down." The hiring manager, Emeka, made a face. 😹 He knew talent was important, but a difficult personality could scatter a team faster than harmattan wind scatters dust. Aisha didn't get the job. Meanwhile, Chinedu, a fresh graduate from UNILAG, was very nervous in his interview for a junior marketing role. He didn't have a lot of practical experience, his CV was mostly filled with academic and internship projects. But Emeka noticed something else. Chinedu was humble, eager to learn, and his eyes lit up when Emeka talked about the company's mission. He spoke passionately about his willingness to work hard and contribute. He even admitted, "I don't know everything, but I'm a fast learner, and I'm ready to put in the work." Emeka smiled. He saw potential. Chinedu got the job. This kind of thing happens all the time, even here in Nigeria. Companies know that skill can be taught. You can send someone to coding school, you can train them on new software. But character? That's harder to change. A "pepper dem" attitude, even with skills, can spoil the whole soup. It can cause wahala in the office, make teamwork impossible, and create a toxic environment. Think about it. Would you rather work with someone who's brilliant but arrogant, who looks down on others and starts gbas gbos over every small thing? Or would you prefer someone who's respectful, collaborative, and brings good vibes to the team, even if they're still learning some things? Most people would choose the latter. Nigerian and foreign businesses, big and small, understand this. They know that a person with good character, someone who's honest, hardworking, and a team player, will be more valuable in the long run. They'll be loyal, they'll adapt to changes, and they'll contribute to a positive work culture. And that kind of value, my friend, is priceless.

## About
As a driven and aspiring software engineer, I am passionate about exploring the fields of distributed systems and data analysis. I believe these areas are pivotal in solving some of the world's most significant challenges. I am currently honing my skills and knowledge in software engineering, with the goal of leveraging technology to create meaningful impact.
One of my major life goals is to contribute to making Ghana and the world a better place through innovation in agriculture. I envision using advanced technology to enhance efficiency and sustainability in agricultural practices, addressing key issues and driving positive change.
I am a natural problem solver with a strong entrepreneurial mindset. I thrive on challenges and approach problems with creativity and persistence. My determination and resilience ensure that I don't back down easily, continually pushing forward to achieve my goals.
I am eager to connect with like-minded professionals and learn from industry leaders. I am committed to growing my expertise and am excited about the opportunities to innovate and make a difference through technology.

During the just concluded semester as a computer science student, I was working with a friend on a CTF and we kept getting stuck; not on the technical challenges, but on coordination. Keeping up with what he had done and where I should come in was a struggle. This became a food-for-thought for me for a project given in my “A modern programming language” course (C#, which included software construction, design patterns, defensive programming, etc) where I was given the “Singleton Design Pattern” to work on. I thought, what if there was a coordination system for penetration testing where everyone could access a central manager and see what every other person has done? That idea became my project. Instead of a basic example, I built a solution to this coordination problem. The Problem: Penetration testing teams often face: - multiple testers accidentally scanning the same ports which could slow down the target systems - duplicate work efforts because everyone assumes someone else tested them - poor tracking of discoveries and progress My Solution: A centralized coordination system using thread-safe Singleton implementation that: - prevents duplicate port scanning (conflict prevention) - manages real-time service assignments across team members - integrates with actual security tools (nmap, curl, smbclient) - automatically detects and resolves tester conflicts - shares vulnerability discoveries immediately with the entire team I tested it against Metasploitable 2 environment and successfully coordinated concurrent users while detecting real vulnerabilities including vsftpd backdoor. You can find full technical details on my Medium and complete source code on GitHub. https://lnkd.in/dbdE3eQu https://lnkd.in/dz-vv-ms #CyberSecurity #PenetrationTesting #SoftwareEngineering #DesignPatterns #CSharp #CTF

[
Olumide D. Fakorede
](https://ng.linkedin.com/in/od-fakorede?trk=public_profile_relatedPosts_face-pile-cta)["Day 29/30: Dear future Semicolon student - it's hard, but you're stronger" "When will I finally start coding?" That was me, week 3 of Semicolon Africa, sitting through another Design Thinking session, desperately wanting to get my hands dirty with actual code. Nine months later, building Koojoo and interviewing real ajo users, I found myself wishing for more Design Thinking classes. To everyone considering or starting Semicolon: 1. Don't give up when it feels like a lot (because it IS a lot) The pace is intentionally fast. You'll move from basic syntax to OOP to advanced concepts like design patterns and TDD. Add Smart Contracts, Data Science and DevOps to the mix, and yes, it's overwhelming. That feeling? It's not a bug, it's a feature. You're being stretched to think like an engineer. 2. Embrace the "boring" classes you want to skip Design Thinking felt like a delay when I wanted to code. But when Mama Adunni struggled with my ArtshopNG interface, I realized - you can't build solutions for people you don't understand. Industrial Design with Mr. Paul Adedapo Akintunde MA RCA MCSD MNIA ARCON taught conceptualization, control, and understanding of time and design processes. It showed me that every interface decision has research behind it. Henley Business School with Dr. Adeyinka Adewale, PhD was mind-shifting. "Who are you, who do you know, and what do you know?" forced me to think beyond code to business impact. 3. You need a system Block time for concepts vs. implementation Document what you build, not just what you learn Your cohort isn't competition, they're your support system Take breaks before you need them 4. Work on projects outside the curriculum ArtshopNG failed spectacularly, but taught me more about real-world development than any tutorial. Build something, break something, fix something. 5. Leverage community power When I almost gave up on a complex algorithm, it wasn't the instructor who saved me - it was a classmate who stayed up debugging with me until 3 AM. 6. Buckle down and do the hard work Month 1: "I don't understand anything" Month 3: "I understand some things" Month 6: "I'm building real solutions" Month 9: "I'm teaching others" The transformation isn't just technical - it's mental. You'll stop asking "Can I build this?" and start asking "How should I build this?" That shift separates Semicolon graduates from bootcamp completers. To current students: Break down that overwhelming project, ask for help, and remember - everyone in your cohort is struggling with something too. To future applicants: It's intentionally challenging. The people who make it aren't the smartest - they're the ones who don't give up when it gets uncomfortable. Semicolon doesn't just teach you to code. It teaches you to think like someone who solves problems with code. #DevWithDynamitesC23 #SemicolonAfrica #CodingBootcamp #FutureStudents #LearningJourney #DesignThinking #CommunitySupport #TechEducation #GrowthMindset
